Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RUI: Carotenoid trade-offs in a species with reversed sexual dichromatism: environmental influences and fitness consequences
Award.AbstractNarration: Animals must make economical decisions about how to distribute limiting resources in order to maintain health and survival. The investigators focus on carotenoid pigments, a particularly important and limiting resource in the diets of human and non-human animals. Vertebrate animals cannot synthesize carotenoids and must obtain them from dietary sources which may be available in only limited quantities. Carotinoids they play three important - and sometimes competing - roles in animal physiology. First, carotenoids are directly responsible for many examples of red, orange and yellow coloration in animals, and this coloration is often necessary for attracting mates. Second, carotenoids in the bloodstream or stored in tissue support the immune system. Third, carotenoids are important antioxidants, which protect the body's cells by removing potentially damaging molecules called free radicals. The carotenoid trade-off hypothesis predicts that when dietary carotenoids are limiting, animals will allocate existing carotenoids to whichever tissue type is most beneficial to them at that time. The investigators take a unique approach to exploring this hypothesis by studying carotenoid trade-offs in female, convict cichlids, Amatitlania nigrofasciata, Central American fish in which females - not males - are brightly colored. Females have the added constraint of allocating carotenoids to their eggs to facilitate offspring survival. The investigators will combine laboratory and field research to examine how environmental stressors such as predators and parasites influence carotenoid allocation strategies, and how these strategies impact health, attractiveness, and offspring survival. Because all vertebrate animals rely in some way on carotenoids, this research will provide fundamental insights into how ingesting and properly allocating essential nutrients affects both physiology and reproduction. This proposal includes a significant training component, as both principal investigators will train and mentor undergraduate and graduate students at their institutions. They will also work with Nicaraguan collaborators to increase research infrastructure at a Nicaraguan biological field station and train Nicaraguan students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When resources are limited, animals are forced to make trade-offs if these resources are necessary for multiple functions. Carotenoid pigments are excellent examples of such limiting resources. Vertebrates cannot synthesize their own carotenoids, however many yellow, orange and red animals rely heavily on these pigments for their coloration. While these pigments are important for attracting mates, they are also essential for the immune system and to reduce oxidative stress in cells by the removal of harmful free radicals. Many people are familiar with the anti-oxidant benefits of fruits and vegetables – these benefits are due to carotenoids. The carotenoid trade-off hypothesis predicts that when dietary intake of carotenoids is limited, animals will be compelled to allocate existing carotenoids to whichever function (e.g. coloration or immunity) is most essential. Most previous work on this subject has focused on male animals, because they tend to be more brightly colored. This project focuses on carotenoid allocation in Neotropical fish called the convict cichlid, Amantitlania nigrofasciata, in which females have orange carotenoid coloration that males lack.

 

The specific aims of the proposal are to: (1) identify whether changes in diet cause female cichlids to allocate carotenoids to meet different needs; (2) explore how carotenoid allocation impacts mate attractiveness, resistance to pathogens, and offspring survival; and (3) determine whether tissue carotenoid content varies predictably with the pressures that females face in their natural habitat, a volcanic crater lake in Nicaragua. We found that increased consumption of carotenoids increased yellow coloration in females, as well as allocation of carotenoids to their ovaries. Females fed supplemental carotenoids produced offspring that grew more rapidly. However, females were not forced to decrease their own use of carotenoids, which is inconsistent with the trade-off hypothesis. Females who consumed more carotenoids were able to rid themselves of bacterial infections more rapidly, but these additional carotenoids did not protect them against oxidative stress. Most significantly, the carotenoid content of female diets in nature was greater than that necessary to suppress bacterial infections, suggesting that females are not carotenoid limited. Finally, we also (and unintentionally) found that some males mimic female coloration as a strategy to obtain more mates. These and other finding were published in eight peer-reviewed publications from 2013-2017.

             

Nicaragua is the second-poorest nation in the Western Hemisphere. A portion of our research was conducted at a research station at Lake Xiloá, Nicaragua, where we made substantial contributions and infrastructure improvements. Funds from our grant were used to purchase an air compressor to fill scuba tanks, which will facilitate the research efforts of both Nicaraguan and international researchers at this site for years to come. Furthermore, our research activities provided essential employment for station staff; in some cases the salaries earned from our short visits were enough to sustain their families for the year. In the course of this project, one Ph.D. student and eight undergraduate students received extensive professional training.  Students were involved in every stage of research, from data collection and analysis to writing and revising manuscripts. Eight of these nine students were women. The Ph.D. student is now a postdoctoral researcher in the School of Public Health at the University of Massachusetts. Of the eight undergraduates, five are currently pursuing their M.D., Ph.D. or M.P.H. degrees at institutions such as Johns Hopkins, Stanford, and Columbia. Thus, the project had a positive impact on the training of future doctors and scientists, particularly among women.
